contextId.information: Job speaks of his friends being unfaithful to him as being like a "wadi" which is a stream that can suddenly dry up. Also, Job refers to his friends ironically here as his "brothers." AT: "But my friends are unfaithful to me. They are like a desert streambed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
contextId.quote: But my brothers have been as faithful to me as a desert streambed

contextId.information: Job compares how quickly his days are passing by to a fast runner. AT: "My days pass swiftly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: My days are swifter than a running messenger

contextId.information: Job compares how quickly his days are passing by to the speed of fast boats. AT: "They pass quickly by like papyrus reed boats" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: They are as fast as papyrus reed boats

contextId.information: Possible meanings of this simile are 1) God hunts Job like a lion hunts its prey or 2) Job is like a lion being hunted by God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: you hunt me down like a lion

contextId.information: If it is easier in your language, you can put this phrase at the beginning of verse 18 and adjust the text accordingly. AT: "You destroy the hopes of man, just like ... dust of the earth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Like this, you destroy the hopes of man

contextId.information: Feces mixes in with the ground and disappears. The reference to feces may also imply that the wicked person is worthless. AT: "will perish permanently like his feces, which completely disappears in the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: will perish permanently like his own feces

contextId.information: The murderer kills in secret just like a thief steals without anyone seeing what he does. AT: "he kills people secretly, just like a thief steals secretly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: he is like a thief

contextId.information: The thick darkness is as comfortable for the wicked as light of the morning is for normal people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: For all of them, thick darkness is like the morning

contextId.information: Foam lasts only a short time. This emphasizes how quickly God will cause the wicked to disappear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like foam on the surface of the waters

contextId.information: Job says that sinners will disappear in Sheol in the same way as snow melts and disappears when it becomes warm. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: As drought and heat melt away ... those who have sinned

contextId.information: These wicked people will be cut off in the same way heads of grain are cut off during harvest. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God will cut them off like a farmer cuts off the top of a stalk of grain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: they will be cut off like the tops of ears of grain

contextId.information: Here "heaps up" is a metonym meaning gather much. Job speaks as if the silver was as easy to get as dust. AT: "gathers large piles of silver" or "gathers silver as easily as he could gather dust" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: heaps up silver like the dust

contextId.information: A spider web is fragile and easily destroyed. AT: "He builds his house as fragile as a spider builds its web" or "He builds his house as fragile as a spider's web" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: He builds his house like a spider

contextId.information: People waited for Job patiently and expected to hear good things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: They always waited for me as they waited for rain

contextId.information: Job speaks of the men crying out in hunger as if they were wild donkey making a loud noise. AT: "cried out like wild donkeys because they were hungry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: brayed like donkeys

contextId.information: Job speaks of his prosperity ending as if it were a cloud that was blown away. Here "prosperity" may refer to well-being or safety. AT: "I no longer prosper at all" or "I am no longer safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: my prosperity passes away as a cloud

contextId.information: While wine is fermenting, gas collects in the container. If the gas is not let out the container will burst. Elihu means that he has so much to say that if he does not speak he feels like he will burst. Also, these two phrases are parallel and have the same meaning. AT: "I feel like my breast is about to burst, like a container of fermenting wine that has no vent" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: my breast is like fermenting wine that has no vent ... like new wineskins, it is ready to burst

contextId.information: This speaks of the man being healed and his body growing strong again as if his body became new like a child's body. AT: "the sick man's body will become new again like a young person's body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: his flesh will become fresher than a child's

contextId.information: This phrase compares the way that these people die to how criminal die. AT: "He kill them for their wicked deeds, in the open sight of other as if they were criminals" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: In the open sight of others, he kills them for their wicked deeds like criminals

contextId.information: "tie your robe up around your waist like a man." Men tied up their robes around their waist so that their legs could move more freely. The idiom "gird up your loins like a man" means to get ready to do something involving action such as work, a contest, or a battle, and Job was to prepare for the hard work of answering God. AT: "get yourself ready for hard work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: gird up your loins like a man

contextId.information: At nighttime, people cannot see clearly, but in the morning the light reveals the distinct shape of everything, just like a seal creates distinct images in clay. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: The earth is changed in appearance like clay changes under a seal

contextId.information: A man who tucks his robe up under his sash or belt is preparing for hard physical work, and Job was to prepare for the hard work of answering God. Translate as in [[:en:bible:notes:job:38:01|38:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: gird up your loins like a man

contextId.information: The arm is a metonym for the strength in the arm. AT: "strength like God's strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: arm like God's

contextId.information: Cedar is a very hard wood, and his tail becomes very hard. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like a cedar

contextId.information: A rock does not change and become soft. Possible meanings are 1) Leviathan's physical chest and the organs inside it are physically hard or 2) Leviathan is not afraid of anything or 3) Leviathan is spoken of as a person who kills without ever being sorry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
contextId.quote: His heart is as hard as a stone

contextId.information: "He thinks of weapons made of iron as if they were weapon made of straw" Straw would not get through his hide, and iron weapons do not get through his hide. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: He thinks of iron as if it were straw
